item.description: This was one of these weird weeks where I didn‚Äôt have much on - because it was my time off between two jobs. It was a bit like a staycation? But in a new place? Lots of life-admin. Where did I leave you? Ah yes‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• This was one of these weird weeks where I didn‚Äôt have much on - because it was my time off between two jobs. It was a bit like a staycation? But in a new place? Lots of life-admin.

  • Where did I leave you? Ah yes, watching Garfield on the plane. Tray table went up, we landed, we taxied and we disembarked. Now for the moment I was dreading: I went to the immigration counter for residents and was presented with my very own residence card. Phew - that was easy. And then both it and my passport were taken from me and I was asked to take a seat and wait. Uh-oh. After what felt like an eternity (a few minutes) both were handed back and I was allowed through: I‚Äôd given the wrong post-code.

  • Collected my bags, and met an agent who handed me my SIM card, keys, and a few other bits I‚Äôd need, before escorting me to a taxi. On the way I plug in my new SIM card on the way, message a few people to let them know I‚Äôve landed. Before I knew it, we‚Äôve arrived and I‚Äôm standing alone on a brand new street with two suitcases, a backpack and some documents to keep me company. And I now understand the confusion at border control: There's no building by the name I've been given.

    ‚Ä¶

item.content:encoded:
• This was my last week at the FT, something I kept very close to my chest. It surprised a few people. Truth be told it didn‚Äôt really sink in for me until this week. I spent the entire week trying to remain composed.

  • Why leave? The exit survey poses that question expectantly. It‚Äôs simple: I‚Äôm relocating and circumstances [editor‚Äôs note: including but not only my age] made now the right time. Where to? Tokyo. I‚Äôve wanted to do it since 2017, so, you know. That‚Äôs why. This has been in the works for a hot minute.

  • Bluesky is really popping off huh.

item.title: Weeknotes: Thirty Hours ‚Äî Week 45, 2024
item.description: Much of my week was spent with the US elections, making sure that reporting worked as well as it could. Looking after the systems and tools telling the news makes it easier to detach from the news. However it isn‚Äôt‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• Much of my week was spent with the US elections, making sure that reporting worked as well as it could. Looking after the systems and tools telling the news makes it easier to detach from the news. However it isn‚Äôt always easy to stay detached: That‚Äôs the rub.

  • This week in data:

    • üß¶ Sponsored socks worn: 3 pairs.
    • üçñ Meat consumed: 0 grams.
    • üìß Emails deleted: 6251 threads.

  • Bluesky is now my primary social media network. If you don‚Äôt already, give me a follow!

  • Coverage of the US election took up the entirety of the first few days of the week, with Tuesday and Wednesday turning into something of an all-nighter. We were prepared for a several-day marathon, but it quickly became clear that this was much shorter (yet faster) sprint instead.

  • It all went rather smoothly. We got some delightful feedback from some readers ‚Äî and several million page-views in the first day. That‚Äôs the upside, or, a ‚Äúreason to be cheerful‚Äù as GC would put it.

  • A lot can change in thirty hours: There's now a lot of commentary floating around, and with the exception of a few interesting anecdotes such as The Bronx being the biggest swing, I'm mostly blocking it out. Especially the hit-pieces rushing to apportion some blame. Mostly those, actually. It isn't that I'm apolitical ‚Äî I am not ‚Äî or even that I want this blog to be: I am just still processing, as I'm sure many others are too.

    ‚Ä¶

  • I have glasses now, sort-of. I can see totally fine without them - but over the years I‚Äôve developed an astigmatism and so they‚Äôre really helping with situations with contrasting bright lights. Still figuring out when to wear them.

  • In very exciting work news, CCC ‚Äî which I‚Äôve here and there since its kick-off last April ‚Äî is now finally live, debuted this week by Joanna Kao‚Äôs excellent article on AI-assisted accessibility tooling, and how they aren‚Äôt what they seem. It was a monumental effort getting there and the change seems subtle, but is profound: Previously an article with inline functionality like that would not work on the main website or app. The same is true of most news organisations and so I'm very excited to see where this capability goes!

    ‚Ä¶
